user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_dir_open:
```c
int lfs_dir_open(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir, const char *path) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_dir_open(%p, %p, \"%s\")", (void*)lfs, (void*)dir, path);
    LFS_ASSERT(!lfs_mlist_isopen(lfs->mlist, (struct lfs_mlist*)dir));

    err = lfs_dir_open_(lfs, dir, path);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_dir_open -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_dir_open:
#define LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0)
...
#define LFS_UNLOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg)
...
#define LFS_ASSERT(test) assert(test)
...
#define LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) 
...
static bool lfs_mlist_isopen(struct lfs_mlist *head,
        struct lfs_mlist *node) {
    for (struct lfs_mlist **p = &head; *p; p = &(*p)->next) {
        if (*p == (struct lfs_mlist*)node) {
            return true;
        }
    }

    return false;
}
...
static int lfs_dir_open_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_dir_t *dir, const char *path) {
    lfs_stag_t tag = lfs_dir_find(lfs, &dir->m, &path, NULL);
    if (tag < 0) {
        return tag;
    }

    if (lfs_tag_type3(tag) != LFS_TYPE_DIR) {
        return LFS_ERR_NOTDIR;
    }

    lfs_block_t pair[2];
    if (lfs_tag_id(tag) == 0x3ff) {
        // handle root dir separately
        pair[0] = lfs->root[0];
        pair[1] = lfs->root[1];
    } else {
        // get dir pair from parent
        lfs_stag_t res = lfs_dir_get(lfs, &dir->m, LFS_MKTAG(0x700, 0x3ff, 0),
                LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_STRUCT, lfs_tag_id(tag), 8), pair);
        if (res < 0) {
            return res;
        }
        lfs_pair_fromle32(pair);
    }

    // fetch first pair
    int err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &dir->m, pair);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    // setup entry
    dir->head[0] = dir->m.pair[0];
    dir->head[1] = dir->m.pair[1];
    dir->id = 0;
    dir->pos = 0;

    // add to list of mdirs
    dir->type = LFS_TYPE_DIR;
    lfs_mlist_append(lfs, (struct lfs_mlist *)dir);

    return 0;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other control expressions in the presented code do not appear to be invariant and therefore do not need investigation under Rule 14.3: - The checks in lfs_dir_open_ (e.g. if (tag < 0), if (lfs_tag_type3(tag) != LFS_TYPE_DIR), if (lfs_tag_id(tag) == 0x3ff)) use values returned from functions or computed from runtime data, so they are not constant. - The subsequent if (err) after lfs_dir_fetch and other error checks use runtime return values, not compile-time constants. - The for loop in lfs_mlist_isopen (for (struct lfs_mlist **p = &head; *p; p = &(*p)->next)) uses *p as the loop condition which depends on the runtime list content (head), so it is not invariant. - LFS_ASSERT and LFS_TRACE are not control statements (LFS_ASSERT expands to assert(...) and LFS_TRACE is an empty macro here), so they are not relevant to Rule 14.3 controlling-expression invariance. The only constructs that produce a controlling expression that is effectively a compile-time constant (and thus should be investigated) are the LFS_LOCK macro as defined and its immediate use in the if (err) test in lfs_dir_open.
